A.abdomen: the part of the body that contains the stomach and intestines
A.abolish: to put an end to something, such as an organization, rule, or custom
A.abrogation: the repeal or abolition of a law, right, or agreement
A.ado: a state of agitation or fuss, especially about something unimportant
A.aerial: radio wave transmitter or receiver; operating in the air
A.amalgam: a blend or combination; an alloy of mercury with another metal
A.ante: a stake put up by a player in poker before receiving cards
A.apt: suitable or right for a particular situation
A.arid: very dry; having little or no rain
A.auspicious: showing the signs of future success

B.balk: hesitate or be unwilling to accept an idea or undertaking
B.bayonet: a blade that can be attached to the end of a rifle and used as a weapon
B.bifurcate: to divide into two parts; to fork into two branches
B.brawny: physically strong and with big muscles
B.bridle: headgear for controlling a horse, consisting of straps and a bit and reins

C.candid: honest and telling the truth, especially about something difficult or painful
C.careen: to go forward, esp. quickly, while moving from side to side
C.chastise: punish, beat, spank, whip; discipline, berate, scold
C.circadian: biological processes that occur regularly at 24-hour intervals
C.cleave: 1) to split apart; 2) to cling or stick
C.clincher: finishing touch, something decisive, such as fact, argument, or point scored
C.coax: to persuade someone gently to do something, by appearing to be kind and patient
C.complacent: feeling so satisfied with your own abilities or situation that you feel you do not need to try any harder
C.concede: admit that something is true or valid after first denying or resisting it; surrender or yield (something that one possesses)
C.constituent: one of the parts that a substance or combination is made of
C.contingency: an unknown or unforeseen future event or condition
C.contraption: a device or machine that looks awkward or old-fashioned
C.convalescent: recovering from an illness or operation
C.convene: come or bring together for a meeting or activity; assemble
C.cornucopia: a symbol of plenty; a goat's horn overflowing with flowers, fruit, and corn
C.crag: a steep rugged rock or peak
C.cul-de-sac: a road with one end blocked off

D.decry: to criticize something as bad, without value, or unnecessary
D.deign: do something that one considers to be beneath one's dignity
D.deter: to discourage or prevent someone from doing something by instilling fear or doubt in them
D.dictum: a formal pronouncement from an authoritative source
D.dilute: (of a liquid) made thinner or weaker by having had water or another solvent added to it
D.dollop: a small amount of a substance/food
D.dwindle: diminish gradually in size, amount, or strength

E.edict: a decree or order given by any authority
E.emanate: to come or seem to come from someone or something
E.eminent: famous and respected within a particular sphere or profession; (of good qualities) unusual; excellent
E.esprit de corps: the feelings, such as being proud and loyal, shared by members of a group of people
E.exert: to use influence, authority, etc. forcefully or effectively
E.exhume: to dig up something buried, esp. a corpse

F.facsimile: an exact copy, especially of a document; reproduction
F.fickle: changing frequently, especially as regards one's loyalties, interests, or affection
F.flay: to strip off the skin; to criticize severely
F.flog: to beat someone very hard with a whip
F.flotsam: the wreckage of a ship or its cargo found floating on or washed up by the sea
F.foray: a short raid or incursion into enemy territory, especially to obtain something

G.gambol: to run and jump in a happy way
G.gerund: a word ending in '-ing' that is made from a verb and is used like a noun
G.gratuitous: unjustified or unreasonable; given or received without charge or obligation
G.grope: feel about or search blindly or uncertainly with the hands

H.helical: having the shape or form of a helix; spiral
H.hoist: to raise or lift up, esp. by mechanical means; any apparatus or device for lifting things

IJ.impetus: the force or energy with which a body moves
IJ.impostor: a person who pretends to be someone else in order to deceive others
IJ.in vitro: happening outside the body in artificial conditions, often in a test tube
IJ.incarnation: a person who embodies in the flesh a deity, spirit, or abstract quality
IJ.incentive: something that encourages a person to do something
IJ.inception: the beginning of a project or an organization or official activity
IJ.infraction: an occasion when someone breaks a rule or law
IJ.ipso facto: by that very fact or act
IJ.jettison: to abandon or give up; to throw overboard

KLM.kinship: blood relationship; the state of having common characteristics
KLM.lax: not sufficiently strict, severe, or careful; (of the limbs or muscles) relaxed
KLM.liaison: communication or cooperation which facilitates a close working relationship between people or organizations
KLM.lusty: healthy, energetic, and full of strength and power
KLM.morsel: a small piece of something, esp. of food
KLM.mundane: everyday, ordinary, and therefore not very interesting

NO.natter: to talk continuously for a long time without any particular purpose
NO.obverse: the other side of something, a counterpart or opposite
NO.ornate: having a lot of complicated decoration
NO.outstrip: move faster than and overtake (someone else)

P.pane: a flat piece of glass, used in a window or door
P.perennial: lasting throughout the year or through many years
P.permeate: to spread through something and be present in every part of it
P.pervade: (esp. of a smell) spread through and be perceived in every part of
P.pest: an insect or small animal that is harmful or damages crops; (informal) an annoying person, esp. a child
P.precedence: formal order of rank or position
P.pristine: new or almost new, and in very good condition
P.procure: to obtain something, esp. after an effort
P.prodigious: extremely great in ability, amount, or strength
P.provenance: the place of origin of something

QR.quell: to stop something, especially by using force
QR.quid pro quo: one thing, esp. an advantage or object, given in exchange for another
QR.raffle: a lottery, often to raise money for charity, in which the prizes are goods rather than money
QR.rebuff: reject (someone or something) in an abrupt or ungracious manner
QR.recant: to take back (a former belief or statement) publicly
QR.recession: a period of temporary economic decline; (Astronomy) motion away from an observer
QR.refute: prove (a statement or theory) to be wrong or false; disprove
QR.remedial: providing or intended as a remedy; of special teaching for slow learners
QR.renounce: formally declare one's abandonment of (a claim, right, or possession)
QR.replete: (pleasantly) full of food and drink; well supplied
QR.reticence: the quality of being unwilling to speak about your thoughts or feelings
QR.romp: to play in a rough, excited, and noisy way

S.salvo: the action of firing several guns at the same time
S.sanctimonious: acting as if morally better than others
S.saucer: a small, curved plate that you put a cup on
S.scourge: to beat someone with a whip; to cause great suffering or a lot of trouble
S.scowl: an angry or bad-tempered facial expression
S.seethe: (of a liquid) bubble up as a result of being boiled
S.singe: to burn slightly without setting alight; scorch
S.slither: to move easily and quickly across a surface while twisting or curving
S.smithereens: a lot of very small broken pieces
S.smoking gun: a piece of incontrovertible incriminating evidence
S.snare: a trap for birds or small animals
S.soliloquy: a speech made by a person while alone, esp. in a play
S.solstice: the time (twice each year) at which the sun reaches its maximum or minimum declination, marked by the longest and shortest days
S.stratify: to arrange the different parts of something in separate layers or groups
S.stratum: any of the distinct layers into which certain rocks are divided
S.stymie: to prevent something from happening or someone from achieving a purpose
S.sublime: extremely good, beautiful, or enjoyable; very great
S.suite: a set of (connected rooms in a hotel, furniture or related software products)
S.sully: to ruin (someone's reputation); to spoil or make dirty
S.sultry: (of weather or climate) very hot and humid; suggesting hidden passion
S.syllabus: the subjects studied for a particular course; a list of these subjects

T.tantamount: to equivalent in effect to; virtually the same as
T.tattle: to secretly tell someone in authority, especially a teacher
T.temporize: avoid making a decision in order to gain time
T.tenet: one of the principles on which a belief or theory is based
T.testy: easily annoyed and not patient; irritable or touchy
T.transcend: to go above or beyond what is expected or normal; to overcome or be superior to
T.trifle: a thing of little or no value or significance

UV.unguent: an ointment; a soft greasy or viscous substance
UV.vascular: relating to the vessels that conduct and circulate body fluids
UV.vat: a large container for holding or storing liquids
UV.vermin: small animals collectively, such as insects and rodents, that spread disease and damage crops

WXYZ.wade: walk with effort through water or another liquid or viscous substance
WXYZ.wanton: (of something bad, such as damage, cruelty, waste) extreme and showing no care at all
WXYZ.witticism: a remark that is both clever and humorous
WXYZ.woe: big problems or troubles; extreme sadness
